20110122020934.000|20110122020936.000|TR0|responsibility to other people and so you 
20110122020936.000|20110122020938.000|TR0|continue to be involved.
20110122020938.000|20110122020940.000|TR0|
20110122020940.000|20110122020943.000|TR0|MORGAN:  When you -- when you just 
20110122020943.000|20110122020945.000|TR0|returned from Sudan, for those who have 
20110122020945.000|20110122020947.000|TR0|never been there, actually describe for us 
20110122020947.000|20110122020949.000|TR0|what -- what it's like on the ground there.
20110122020949.000|20110122020951.000|TR0|
20110122020951.000|20110122020954.000|TR0|G. CLOONEY:  It depends on where you are.  
20110122020954.000|20110122020956.000|TR0|We were in several different places.  
20110122020956.000|20110122020958.000|TR0|Abyei is a region right on the border that 
20110122020958.000|20110122021000.000|TR0|is disputed.  The border is disputed.  The 
20110122021000.000|20110122021002.000|TR0|amount of profit-sharing is disputed.  
20110122021002.000|20110122021005.000|TR0|There are the Misserya and the Ngok Dinka 
20110122021005.000|20110122021007.000|TR0|are the two tribes that basically one is 
20110122021007.000|20110122021009.000|TR0|nomadic and grazes through the -- through 
20110122021009.000|20110122021011.000|TR0|the Abyei Region, but they're there for 
20110122021011.000|20110122021013.000|TR0|only about three months. That's from the 
20110122021013.000|20110122021016.000|TR0|north.  And the southerners are mostly 
20110122021016.000|20110122021018.000|TR0|farmers and they live there.
